event.title: belonged to Gregorie Sarpy and Charles Gratiot; by 1890

data.event: The land which became Shrewsbury originally belonged to Gregorie Sarpy and Charles Gratiot; by 1890, it was divided into farms and sold to families.
The area now known as Shrewsbury was a 278-acre (1.13 km2) farm owned by General John Murdoch.
In 1913, concerned resident Joseph Burge organized the Shrewsbury Improvement Association to improve Shrewsbury and develop its first sewer system.
Shrewsbury was incorporated and became a village in 1913; shortly thereafter a sanitation system was established, reducing water-borne diseases prevalent at the time.
